ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: In this course, I developed a perspective to see the world from culturally different societies. Invaluable to how I interact with my peers and professors in future classes.

SKILLS: public speaking in Spanish via skits (a really fun highlight!!!) and oral presentations, short-form and longer-form writing (short essays, one longer essay, a podcast, and even poetry which really help you improve your writing!), oral and literary comprehension and analysis via fascinating short films, short stories, and a novel. 
KNOWLEDGE/INSIGHTS: fundamental everyday vocabulary and grammatical structures, knowledge of cultural phenomenons (festivals, social etiquettes, slang, music Sebstian LOVES music) contemporary issues (neocolonialism, ecological justice and crises), and knowledge about each other (this class was a community)!
Grammar and vocabulary skills, reading comprehension and conversational skills.

I learned more about the Spanish language, grammar, and culture. I expected to just learn more Spanish words (like my high school taught me), but was happily surprised that my professor wished to fully immerse his students into the Spanish culture. Never before had I been in a class where only Spanish was spoken.
I learned more about Spanish language constructs and how to express myself through art, essays, and writing with confidence.
I expanded my conversational skills in Spanish and learned how to express myself creatively and artistically through music and writing.
I learned a lot about Spanish culture in specific countries and how to more easily converse in Spanish.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The course is well structured for students who come out of L2 Spanish. Additionally, Sebastian does a great job of connecting with each student, outlining academic goals, and providing a structure beyond the standard syllabus. Sebastian's enthusiasm ensures that the class is engaged regularly.

I am a native Spanish speaker and can speak it fluently at a higher level than an entering L3 student. My lack of writing experience placed me in L3, but I was able to catch up fairly quickly and, at times, found the course to be slightly slow for my development. My instructor did recognize this and recommended me to L4, but this was turned down. At times, I found myself actively not participating in class so the rest of my classmates would have the opportunity to do so. I could see that their pace was entirely appropriate for their Spanish proficiency level, though. If I had been allowed into Spanish L4, I would have found this course more challenging (or as challenging as my L3 peers found it to be).

STRENGTHS: the professor Sebastin, who lets us improve our Spanish in any way we wish (skits, creative writing, poetry, conversation in and out of class, even improv) and is a caring, mindful professor who youll look forward to seeing everyday! I found a perfect balance of oral, writing, and listening practice in this class, along with a blend of formal and informal assignments. No weaknesses for me! While the flow of assignments is steady in this class, its manageable and comes at a predictable, piecemeal pace. In the beginning of the semester I felt at times that we could have done more full-group discussion and public speaking at times, but both these ramped up as the semester went along. Overall, I found Sebastins methodology of blending the informal and formal modes of writing and discussion very helpful.

there were some miscommunications on what work was expected to be turned in for a grade. It could be improved with an improved use of the canvas assignment system where all the graded assignments were posted. There was an available weekly syllabus but the assignments sometimes were assigned differently in class so the syllabus was no longer accurate. Maybe a link to a google document that would update if the instructor changed information would be an improvement. Also some of the VHL assignments were not well graded in that they were often looking for a specific answer that was not readily clear and there wasnt enough info to figure it out.

Strengths: Great resources and the professor offers great, fast feedback. Whenever I emailed my professor, he would answer within minutes (hours at most). 
Weaknesses: At the beginning and middle of the semester, the course work was extremely heavy (about 3 hours of work per day). It lightened up toward the end which was very helpful. Also, Supersite is not a necessity. We paid for a program when the optional worksheets that our professor gave us assessed the same knowledge/ contained the same material.

The course is great at teaching the linguistic structures and how to apply them. It is also great with giving enough time for assignments and breeding a conducive learning environment. One weakness is that sometimes the class feels like it drags due to us meeting 4 times a week.
There were plenty of interesting and engaging assignments but the workload was quite a lot. I also would have liked it if groups for projects were mixed up or randomly assigned.
A strength is its use of student participation and interaction to learn a language.

Strengths: focus on both language and culture, engaging projects, focus on learning rather than assessment-taking

Weakness: slightly disorganized (did not follow syllabus)

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, as long as they are properly placed into their Spanish proficiency course.

Sure would, especially with Sebastin!! He went above and beyond (karaoke, office hours, encouragement) to get to know us as people and get us to know each other (you will make friends in this class, which is honestly one of Sebastins goals). This is the kind of class where the professor will come up and compliment your interest in dragonflies, or ask you how a poem made you feel. Sebastin values honest (and dramatic!!!) expression, growth, music, and the discussion social issues. If you do too, take this class. Youll definitely grow as a student of Spanish!
Yes, it was interesting and a great way to improve my Spanish.

Yes! Spanish with my professor was my favorite class because it was challenging but not impossible. I have made friends in that class and we have all bonded over dinners/ outside meetings. This was the perfect class to begin my mornings, especially when the professor was always in a good mood and ready to share his joy.
I would recommend this course; after taking a year off from Spanish, I can confidently say that this class helped me become entirely more confident with the language.
Yes, if they want to improve their Spanish skills, this course will help them.
I would recommend this class to anyone who is looking for a challenging course to improve their Spanish fluency.
Yes, I feel that my Spanish-writing has significantly improved. My speaking has also improved.
